awd_titl_txt: Reclaiming Access to Inquiry-based Science Education (RAISE) for Incarcerated Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is unique in targeting arguably the most vulnerable learners in the American education system: youth confined in juvenile corrections facilities.  Three primary problems confronting science education in these settings are: (1) inadequate curriculum and resources; (2) inadequately prepared and supported teachers; and (3) a heterogeneous group of learners, many of whom have disabilities, are disengaged, and/or lack reading and mathematics skills.  Failure to address these challenges and the broader educational needs of incarcerated juveniles has broad implications for society, so this project is timely and has high potential for broad impacts.  
 
To address these problems project personnel will employ an iterative development process to develop a curriculum designed to increase access to and mastery of science content, concepts, and inquiry skills critical for careers in the 21st Century STEM workforce.  They will then prepare teachers to implement the program in pilot testing in juvenile corrections facilities in Massachusetts. Specifically, the investigators will: (1) align and adapt an existing biology curriculum using Common Core State Standards and Universal Design for Learning principles; (2) develop all materials, digital supports and scaffolds, virtual learning environments and labs, assessments, and teacher professional development materials for one curriculum unit; (3) conduct usability evaluation of all materials and use the results to refine and finalize two curriculum units; (4) prepare teachers to implement the biology program in juvenile corrections education settings; (5) conduct a quasi-experimental study to examine the impacts of the biology program on the content knowledge and inquiry skills of students, their interests, and their levels of engagement; and, (6) disseminate the findings to various constituency groups.  The final product will be a Universal Design for Learning, project-based inquiry science program that includes virtual learning environments, virtual laboratories, and digital scaffolds and supports that promote scientific learning for incarcerated youth.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Project RAISE (Reclaiming Access to Inquiry Science for Incarcerated Learners) was a collaborative development and research project developed by the University of Massachusetts, Amherst and the Center for Applied Special Technology (CAST). The goal of Project RAISE was to develop and study the impact of a Project-Based Inquiry Science (PBIS) Ecology unit developed within a UDL framework to broaden STEM participation and to improve STEM career interest for youth incarcerated in juvenile corrections settings. Incarcerated youth are perhaps the most vulnerable populations of learners in our educational systems. They are a population that have substantial knowledge and skill deficits, and a majority have diagnosed or undiagnosed special education needs. The nature of correctional settings creates substantial learning challenges to learners and teachers alike. Consequently, students in carceral settings typically lack access to meaningful and authentic science learning experiences. Teachers managing a heterogeneous group of learners with a range of basic academic skills and deficits often revert to the use individualized packets in an effort to meet student needs. Such approaches minimize learning, alienate learners, and diminish the spirit of inquiry that is at the root of science. Consequently, youth involved in the juvenile and adult correctional systems are often viewed from a criminogenic lens and are typically undervalued as learners, especially in STEM fields. 

In Project RAISE we addressed the challenges of science learning in juvenile corrections settings by utilizing iOS tablet-based technologies to create an innovative and immersive learning environment where diverse learners in juvenile corrections facilities could participate in project-based inquiry science in ways that stoked the learning spirit and better prepared them for 21st-century STEM jobs. Through Project RAISE, we partnered with learners incarcerated in a juvenile justice system and their teachers to co-design and co-develop an immersive tablet-based learning environment to teach ecology and to expose students to a range of STEM careers. We co-developed this learning environment in an iOS App that was replete with an extensive array of tools, features, and supports to increase access to learning, expression, and engagement in science. Together, we developed iOS AppBooks - fully encapsulated learning tools that integrated content, assessment, instructional activities, and virtual laboratories in a single learning system. The AppBook system was built from a universal design for learning (UDL) framework that ensured that diverse learners with diverse learning needs could access all content while ensuring diverse learners could demonstrate their learning through multiple modalities. 

Through extensive and recursive usability testing, we found the Project RAISE AppBooks were engaging to learners incarcerated in juvenile corrections settings. We found that students preferred learning through the AppBooks to their typical instruction. Students reported the learning science through the AppBooks were interesting, engaging, and fun. Teachers reported students increased their knowledge of and interest in STEM jobs through the media-based STEM career exploration system that presented STEM jobs as accessible and attainable. 

The iOS App developed through Project RAISE is flexible, expandable, and extendable to different fields and different disciplines. Future research will focus on directly testing impact of AppBook instruction on student learning and developing AppBooks in different areas of learning such as Mathematics, History, and English Literature. 

 


Last Modified: 01/26/2023
Modified by: Michael Krezmien
